Clicked Reading
Warning:
Additional Information:
\nIf the room temperature is below 15°C, it may feel too cold for comfortable sleep. Consider raising the temperature slightly. The ideal temperature is around 18°C.
\nIf the room temperature is above 21°C, it may be too warm for a good night\'s sleep. The ideal temperature is around 18°C.

\nThe ideal room temperature for working is between 22°C and 24°C. Consider adjusting the temperature to this range for comfort and productivity. High temperatures reduce productivity and concentration.
\nTemperature between 20°C and 22°C is ideal for asthmatics, this range will not irritate lungs. Consider adjusting to reduce potential irritation.
\nFor asthmatics, maintain an indoor humidity level between 30% and 50%. Levels above 50% may lead to increased asthma symptoms and difficulty breathing.
\nAbove 60% is harmful for indoor air quality, over long periods of time, this level encourages the growth of mold and dust mites. Use a dehumidifier to lower the humidity percentage.

\nBelow 30% humidity, use a humidifier to maintain 30% to 35%. This will alleviate dryness and prevent eczema flare-ups. Low humidity may cause skin allergies, eye irritation, cracked skin, and respiratory infections.
\nAbove 55%, use a dehumidifier to keep humidity between 30% to 35%. High humidity can promote the growth of mold and bacteria if sustained over long periods, causing health risks and discomfort.
\nIn summer, keep indoor humidity below 50% for optimal comfort. Above 55% can cause discomfort and increase the release of volatile organic compounds (VOCs).
\nIn winter, keep indoor humidity between 30% to 35%. This will prevent condensation on surfaces and minimizes respiratory issues.

\n700 ppm to 1,000 ppm are acceptable, though ventilation may be beneficial to improve air freshness. CO₂ levels between 350 ppm and 450 ppm indicate fresh air, and 450 ppm and 700 ppm are typical for normal indoor air quality.
\nCO₂ levels from 1,000 ppm to 2,500 ppm may cause drowsiness, poor air quality, stale air quality, and discomfort. You must improve air flow for safety.
\nCO₂ above 2,500 ppm can lead to negative health effects, including headaches, sleepiness, and stale, stuffy air. You must improve air flow for safety.
\nLong-term exposure above 1,000 ppm can lead to complaints of fatigue and poor air quality, which may affect focus and concentration. Improve air flow for safety.
\nLevels between 2,000 and 5,000 ppm can cause headaches, drowsiness, poor concentration, and may also increase heart rate and cause slight nausea.
